FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The Phenix City Wastewater Treatment Plant is a 7.75 MGD trickling filter plant.  The average daily flow treated is approximately 5.8 MGD.  The facility is located at the end of State Docks Road in Phenix City Alabama.  This treatment facility is designed to substantially reduce the amount of B.O.D., suspended solids, ammonia, and coliform bacteria contained in the treated water returned to the Chattahoochee River.  After flowing through pretreatment facilities, primary settling basins, trickling filters, and secondary clarifiers the flow reaches the final stage of treatment called disinfection.  The disinfection process requires the use of two hazardous chemicals.  The two chemicals are chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  Because of the large amounts required, enough of the chemicals must be stored on site to support the demand of the system.  This amount ranges from 4000 - 10,000 pounds.  The area in which chemicals are stored is ventilated, and is equiped with a dual point leak detection device.  A minimal leak will be detected and the unit will then actuate the alarm system which includes a floor level mounted exhaust fan, exterior alarm bell, exterior emergency lights, and a remote alarm located in the operations building to warn plant personnel of a possible emergency situation.  This facility is equiped with self contained breathing apparatus and Chlorine Institute emergency chlorine repair kits for ton cylinders.  The plant personnel are all trained professionals and are frequently instructed on safe and correct operational and emergency procedures.  No accidents have occured as a result of the use or accidental release of either chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the past five years.  A worst case scenario release of either of these chemicals could result in the possible evacuation within a three mile radius of the plant.  The local fire department is aware of the location and effects of both chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  In the event of a worst case leak the fir

e department would handle the situation.  The Russel County Emergency Management Agency would also assist with any emergency evacuation or other procedures as needed.  The plant personnel are continuously trained and made aware of any changes in procedures.  The disinfection and chemical storage areas are well maintained.  To ensure a safe working environment, the disinfection system is routinely assessed for any repair needs or upgrades.
